title: Experience porting 4.5k loc of C to Go (Facebook's CSS flexbox implementation Yoga)
Description: Porting Yoga (Facebook's CSS flexbox implementation) from C to Go.

inline_content.Text: Description: Porting Yoga (Facebook's CSS flexbox implementation) from C to Go.

title: I’m working on desktop GUI apps for Windows in Go.

inline_content.Text: I’m working on desktop GUI apps for Windows in Go.

title: As it uses native win32 controls I don’t have to implement my own buttons, list boxes etc.

inline_content.Text: As it uses native win32 controls I don’t have to implement my own buttons, list boxes etc.

title: However, win32 doesn’t have anything to help you layout things on the screen. Manual positioning is painful.

inline_content.Text: However, win32 doesn’t have anything to help you layout things on the screen. Manual positioning is painful.

title: I started looking into a writing a layout engine. There are many systems to be inspired by.

inline_content.Text: I started looking into a writing a layout engine. There are many systems to be inspired by.

title: I did some work in Winforms so I could copy their ideas.

inline_content.Text: I did some work in Winforms so I could copy their ideas.

title: I could look into copying Android layout logic.

inline_content.Text: I could look into copying Android layout logic.

title: I could look into implementing constraint-based layout like in iOS.

inline_content.Text: I could look into implementing constraint-based layout like in iOS.

title: The option I liked the best is CSS flexbox. It’s not the simplest, it’s not the most complicated, but the biggest win is that many people, including myself, are already familiar with it.

inline_content.Text: The option I liked the best is CSS flexbox. It’s not the simplest, it’s not the most complicated, but the biggest win is that many people, including myself, are already familiar with it.

title: I started looking for an implementation in Go. I found one in
shiny
a
https://github.com/golang/exp/tree/master/shiny/widget/flex
project, but it’s simplified implementation.

inline_content.Text: I started looking for an implementation in Go. I found one in

title: The most complete implementation is Facebook’s
Yoga
a
https://github.com/facebook/yoga
, but it’s written in C (with bindings to many languages).

inline_content.Text: The most complete implementation is Facebook’s
, but it’s written in C (with bindings to many languages).

title: I could write cgo bindings but I prefer my Go pure so I decided to manually port C code to Go, all 4.5k lines of it.

inline_content.Text: I could write cgo bindings but I prefer my Go pure so I decided to manually port C code to Go, all 4.5k lines of it.

title: Phase zero - picking a name for the package

inline_content.Text: Phase zero - picking a name for the package

title: It was tempting to pick a name that would be some combination of
yoga
c
and
go
c
e.g.
goyoga
c
or
yoga-go
c

inline_content.Text: It was tempting to pick a name that would be some combination of

title: That would be a bad idea. Including
go
c
in package or repository name is bad (but unfortunately happens too often).

inline_content.Text: That would be a bad idea. Including
in package or repository name is bad (but unfortunately happens too often).

title: My rules for a good name for a Go library are:

inline_content.Text: My rules for a good name for a Go library are:

title: I could use
yoga
c
, to better higlight connection with original project, but it’s not descriptive.

inline_content.Text: , to better higlight connection with original project, but it’s not descriptive.

title: Phase one - getting Go port to compile

inline_content.Text: Phase one - getting Go port to compile

title: You can’t port 4.5k lines of code in one sitting so it was important to have a strategy that allows for making incremental progress.

inline_content.Text: You can’t port 4.5k lines of code in one sitting so it was important to have a strategy that allows for making incremental progress.

title: The important part was keeping track of porting progress. For that I cloned Yoga’s repository. After converting a piece of C code to Go I would delete it from my fork. That way I would keep track of code that still needs to be ported.

inline_content.Text: The important part was keeping track of porting progress. For that I cloned Yoga’s repository. After converting a piece of C code to Go I would delete it from my fork. That way I would keep track of code that still needs to be ported.

title: It’s important to get an early boost so I started with
the simplest parts
a
https://github.com/kjk/flex/commit/4dabacad1ba37403e8b7380b2ccb6c2ed6c8586a
: structures, enums.

inline_content.Text: It’s important to get an early boost so I started with

title: Porting process was boring but relatively uneventful.

inline_content.Text: Porting process was boring but relatively uneventful.

title: Go and C have reversed order of declarations. Reversing it manually is boring and error prone. There were many repeated declarations that I could do with a simple search-and-replace, e.g
YGNodeRef node
c
=>
node *YGNode
c

inline_content.Text: Go and C have reversed order of declarations. Reversing it manually is boring and error prone. There were many repeated declarations that I could do with a simple search-and-replace, e.g

title: search-and-replace
->
c
to
c
as Go uses
c
for both cases (something that C++-28 should adopt)

inline_content.Text: for both cases (something that C++-28 should adopt)

title: Go doesn’t support ternary operator and Yoga’s developers are infatuated with it. That was one part where I had to be extra careful as it was more than mechanical change

inline_content.Text: Go doesn’t support ternary operator and Yoga’s developers are infatuated with it. That was one part where I had to be extra careful as it was more than mechanical change

title: Go doesn’t support
xor
c
(^) and
or
c
(|) operator on bool. As it turns out, they are not neccessary.
x ^ y
c
is the same as
x != y
c
a = a | b
c
can be written as:
if !a && b { a = true }
c

inline_content.Text: (|) operator on bool. As it turns out, they are not neccessary.

title: switch
c
statement needs attention as in C
case
c
falls-through by default

inline_content.Text: statement needs attention as in C

title: Yoga uses
float
c
for coordinates and uses a few functions like
fmaxf
c
etc. Go only implements
float64
c
versions of math functions. Missing functions were easy to write.

inline_content.Text: for coordinates and uses a few functions like
versions of math functions. Missing functions were easy to write.

title: Yoga code was relatively easy to port partly because of lack of string handling, which is where Go and C differ a lot

inline_content.Text: Yoga code was relatively easy to port partly because of lack of string handling, which is where Go and C differ a lot

title: It took me 2 days to port C code to Go, get it compiling and passing some tests. But some tests were failing.

inline_content.Text: It took me 2 days to port C code to Go, get it compiling and passing some tests. But some tests were failing.

title: Yoga has a lot of tests which gave me confidence that when the port is done, I’ll be able to verify its correctness by porting the tests.

inline_content.Text: Yoga has a lot of tests which gave me confidence that when the port is done, I’ll be able to verify its correctness by porting the tests.

title: I ported the code, I started porting the tests and they were failing.

inline_content.Text: I ported the code, I started porting the tests and they were failing.

title: 2 days was enough to mechanically port the code but not even close enough to understand it.

inline_content.Text: 2 days was enough to mechanically port the code but not even close enough to understand it.

title: As far as I can tell you can’t step through tests in the debugger, so I converted a failing test into a test program.

inline_content.Text: As far as I can tell you can’t step through tests in the debugger, so I converted a failing test into a test program.

title: I was pleasently surprised that debugger in Visual Studio Code works decently.

inline_content.Text: I was pleasently surprised that debugger in Visual Studio Code works decently.

title: I found one porting mistake by stepping through the code but fixing it didn’t fix test failures.

inline_content.Text: I found one porting mistake by stepping through the code but fixing it didn’t fix test failures.

title: I spent a bit more time stepping through the code but not knowing what results to expect I decided that it’s not a promising approach.

inline_content.Text: I spent a bit more time stepping through the code but not knowing what results to expect I decided that it’s not a promising approach.

title: I decided to re-check every line of code.

inline_content.Text: I decided to re-check every line of code.

title: Initially I ported the code in random order so I used re-checking time to also re-arrange the code in the same order as C code. That will help re-porting Yoga improvments in the future.

inline_content.Text: Initially I ported the code in random order so I used re-checking time to also re-arrange the code in the same order as C code. That will help re-porting Yoga improvments in the future.

title: It was predictably boring. It took another day, I found 2 more porting bugs.

inline_content.Text: It was predictably boring. It took another day, I found 2 more porting bugs.

title: The tests were still failing and I was a bit stuck.

inline_content.Text: The tests were still failing and I was a bit stuck.

title: I did another pass in the debugger and fortunately an inspiration struck.

inline_content.Text: I did another pass in the debugger and fortunately an inspiration struck.

title: I compared my
fmaxf
c
implementation with C implmentation and it turns out that if one of the arguments is
NaN
c
but the other one isn’t, it should return non-NaN value.

inline_content.Text: implementation with C implmentation and it turns out that if one of the arguments is
but the other one isn’t, it should return non-NaN value.

title: It was easy to fix and that fixed all the tests.

inline_content.Text: It was easy to fix and that fixed all the tests.

title: The code was working but it was far from idiomatic Go code.

inline_content.Text: The code was working but it was far from idiomatic Go code.

title: Next phase was tweaking the API to be more Go-like.

inline_content.Text: Next phase was tweaking the API to be more Go-like.

title: removing
YG
c
prefix as packages obviate the need for that

inline_content.Text: prefix as packages obviate the need for that

title: Some transformations could be done with regex search & replace. The rest with manual labor.

inline_content.Text: Some transformations could be done with regex search & replace. The rest with manual labor.

title: Having lots of tests really helped in making sure that the code is still correct.

inline_content.Text: Having lots of tests really helped in making sure that the code is still correct.

title: The port is finished. It works and passes all Yoga tests.

inline_content.Text: The port is finished. It works and passes all Yoga tests.

title: The API is still a bit awkward by Go standards. Too many methods, not enough direct access to variables.

inline_content.Text: The API is still a bit awkward by Go standards. Too many methods, not enough direct access to variables.

title: Partly it’s because I wanted to stay close to C code so that future changes to Yoga can be ported easily.

inline_content.Text: Partly it’s because I wanted to stay close to C code so that future changes to Yoga can be ported easily.

title: Partly it’s because of implementation choices and the nature of the problem.

inline_content.Text: Partly it’s because of implementation choices and the nature of the problem.

title: There are many flexbox properties, only some are given for any given element. The rest is given default values, which might be undefined.

inline_content.Text: There are many flexbox properties, only some are given for any given element. The rest is given default values, which might be undefined.

title: How to represent that in Go? Ideally, the zero value of the type would represent default value so that a style definition can be constructed as
&Style{}
c
and then we can set the properties that are non-default.

inline_content.Text: How to represent that in Go? Ideally, the zero value of the type would represent default value so that a style definition can be constructed as
and then we can set the properties that are non-default.

title: Unfortunately, that doesn’t work well for properties that are numbers because zero might be a valid value.

inline_content.Text: Unfortunately, that doesn’t work well for properties that are numbers because zero might be a valid value.

title: Yoga uses
float32
c
for numbers and
NaN
c
for undefined value of a CSS property.

inline_content.Text: for undefined value of a CSS property.

title: Another option is used in
sql
c
package for types like
sql.NullString
c
that need to indicate null-abilibility. They are represented as a struct that combines a value and bool field
Valid
c
. Zero value of bool is false, so by default values start as invalid (undefined).

inline_content.Text: that need to indicate null-abilibility. They are represented as a struct that combines a value and bool field
. Zero value of bool is false, so by default values start as invalid (undefined).

title: This isn’t a great API either since it makes setting and reading values more awkward.

inline_content.Text: This isn’t a great API either since it makes setting and reading values more awkward.

title: At the end of the day it’s better to have solid, working code with awkward API than not having the code at all. Full flexbox implementation is not trivial to write.

inline_content.Text: At the end of the day it’s better to have solid, working code with awkward API than not having the code at all. Full flexbox implementation is not trivial to write.

title: Unless someone writes a pure Go implementation designed from scratch with Go idioms in mind,
flex
a
https://github.com/kjk/flex
is the best option.

inline_content.Text: Unless someone writes a pure Go implementation designed from scratch with Go idioms in mind,

title: Go is so close to C. Wouldn’t it be great if there was a program that could take C code and turn it into Go code?

inline_content.Text: Go is so close to C. Wouldn’t it be great if there was a program that could take C code and turn it into Go code?

title: There are few attempts to do that:

inline_content.Text: There are few attempts to do that:

title: elliotchance/c2go
a
https://github.com/elliotchance/c2go
seems to be the most promising.

inline_content.Text: seems to be the most promising.

title: I didn’t try any of them as neither seems to be usable yet.

inline_content.Text: I didn’t try any of them as neither seems to be usable yet.

title: It’s an approach worth keeping an eye on for the future but not yet viable today.

inline_content.Text: It’s an approach worth keeping an eye on for the future but not yet viable today.
